As much as I wish we had a little more freedom with the inventory management, like swapping inventory item's positions and taking out more than 1 item at a time, I kind of understand why they did it like this. To balance out the difficulty, making it so the player needs to make use of the lock feature in the shop and hold off another run or sacrifice an item in your pack to make something fit. 

You can get really OP, really easily if they gave full freedom of organization in this game. If you play your cards right, you should be able to figure out enough spaces for things you need and things you want. This is a minor complaint. 

The other thing is, this game advertises itself as a "Rogue-LIKE" while the game being made and balanced around meta progression that only exists in a Rogue-LITE game. It's miss-marketing itself. This might upset people who would rather play a Rogue-LIKE instead of a Rogue-LITE. But, for me, I much prefer Rogue-LITE games over Rogue-LIKE games. Mainly because I like having a sense of progression in my games. So Rogue-lite games are right down my alley.

The game itself has countless builds you can have that surprisingly work well. But, with any RPG/Wave Survival game, tank builds are discouraged. The issue with this is, due to the way the game adopts the Backpack Battles playstyle, shop RNG can completely ruin your run.

The game lacks synergies that change the way your attacks behave and it doesn't fuse weapons into other, more powerful weapons. What it does offer is some weird passive tiers that don't seem to work properly. You don't have any real idea what goes with what to improve an item's passive boosts.

It's a pretty good game, you get a good bang for your buck with this one. Overall I give it a 4/5, a few balance adjustments for classes and weapon is all that it needs.

The current state of the game is that some classes are so strong that it's an easy win every time on the hardest difficulty (the strongest classes currently, in my opinion, are golem, sentinel and eldritch knight, by round 4-5 they are unkillable) while a few other classes will even struggle slightly on the lowest difficulty. The classes I think need a buff/rework are the adept, knight, weaponmaster, priestess, inquisitor, ranger, duelist, blademaster and rogue.

For some of the classes, namely the knight and blademaster, I think they need a full rework of their kit. The basic knight is just an empty shell of a class, and the blademaster doesn't scale at all. The other weak classes would be fine with just a touch up of the scaling on some of their passives, improving some positive scaling or reducing some negative scaling. The adept class in particular loses HP far too quickly, I've never tested it, but I think it's actually possible to die from leveling up reducing your max hp to 0.

A few classes don't need a buff, but rather a simple weapon addition in their starting weapon selection. These are the Singularist (add claws), Rogue (add shortsword), Crusader (add longsword or halberd), Spellblade (add magic staff), Warlock (add flame wand) and Shaman (add staff of fireball). Each of these weapons are something I would consider central to that class's playstyle and class features, not having it from the start of the run is enough to make playing these classes a struggle, despite the class being strong on paper.

Do you like Brotato? Because that's game that God Of Weapons is most closely aping. 

Obviously Brotato itself is a Vampire Survivors derivative, so God of Weapons is a copy of a copy, but the good news is that Brotato is excellent and, for the most part, GoW knows which notes to play. 

Specifically, characters gain extra benefits from focusing on 2-4 stats, weapons have categories/tags that provide multiplicative bonuses, and most non-weapon items provide a both a smaller debuff along with a larger buff, and sometimes the best way to play is to make a character build that minimizes or negates the effects of the debuffs.  

Where GoW expands, rather than merely iterates, is that it adds backpack management ala Diablo 1/2. Leveling in GoW gives you a tiny HP bump, and, more importantly, two extra squares of inventory space. Not only do weapons and items need to fit in your bag, but many (though not as many as I wish) specific weapons gain bonuses when they're placed adjacent to other specific weapons. 

I also think it's worth noting that GoW features more meta-progression than Brotato. Yes, unlocking characters and weapons is the bulk of the work, but there is a "spend resources between runs to permanently bump your stats" mechanism, too. 

Unfortunately GoW fails in a few areas.

The biggest offender is that the action is a weird 3/4ths overhead view and both the enemy and weapon hit boxes are... tenuous. These two things combine to make it feel like your positioning provides little if any agency. Don't stop moving, spam dash on cooldown, stack some lifesteal, pray. I know this describes most bulletheaven games, but it's worth highlighting how little it matters in this game. 

Second, there's a ton of slowdown, at least on Steam Deck as of late January 2024. Maybe this isn't an issue on more powerful machines but if you're playing this on deck. To be clear, it isn't game breaking, but it is very noticeable. 

While those are going to be the two biggest red flags for most, my biggest issue is the graphics. Visually, this game is soulless. Simplified, chunky, kinda cutesy, generic fantasy 3D models that look straight out of the worst gacha mobile game.  If you measure graphics a scale with Art (complimentary) on one end, and Content (derogatory) on the other, this is has run is off the chart on the Content side. I feel bad calling it out, because making games is hard, but it's impossible not to notice that the graphics in this game are entirely perfunctory.

That said, I've already played for almost 20 hours, it'll probably take another 5-10 hours to finish unlocking everything, and I like it enough to check back every few months when new content drops. I've more than gotten my money's worth.

BUY THIS UNDER $10!!  Each game takes about an hour, but is engaging and fun the entire time. For me, a perfect blend of action action action and then natural pause between rounds to think for as long as I want.  Highly, HIGHLY recommend, especially for a game of this price point.  I paid about $6, and now that I've played it I would've paid 3X that much for it.  Will be buying and gifting to my Steam friends.  It's awesome, and they don't need to know it was $6!  I haven't played it on controller yet, just WASD, but I bet it would play even better on controller.  Finally, the progression up to different characters and going after Achievements is well-thought and doable and adds just that much more polish to a very fun game on its own.  I get one or two achievements per session, and that's just about perfect to keep me interested in coming back to try another one.  Dev recommend: Complicate the floor a bit more so it's a tad more maze-like instead of always rectangles running in circles.  And maybe randomize the buffs on each item a bit more, so I have some harder choices.  And finally, a little more documentation to understand when buffs are weapon-specific vs. universal.  But these are recommendations, not complaints.  PLAY THIS GAME!

TLDR: Game can be fun at its core but there are some drawbacks such as that the game severely lacking polish, quality of life improvements, sound effects and music, game being really unbalanced with some things being orders of magnitude better than others, progression being slow, inventory management is clunky which makes it take twice as long as in similar games to do things and is not very controller friendly so will also be not be that great to control on steam deck. Overall it feels like early access.

Some examples of issues:

Bugs:
After selecting a character to play, sometimes character would not move when I moved controller stick, but all the other controller buttons worked.
Being able to combine the items even when the game says that you can't afford it.

Controls:
I used controller the whole time and the button layout is just very unintuitive. For example every other game uses some version of RB and LB for rotating the item in inventory. This game uses X button to rotate so you can only rotate in one direction and the RB and LB buttons do nothing while holding the item so there is a lot of missed opportunity in how the game controls.

Quality of life features:
You cannot leave mid run and continue your run later, even though the game is wave based and pauses between waves to let you manage your inventory creating a perfect opportunity to jump off and return later.
When you want to go to bottom of the list, pressing up while at the top does not take you down to the bottom, instead if you want to check what the stats at the bottom do you need to press down like  20 times.
You can't swap item in inventory with one being held at the moment. If you want to swap locations of two items of the same size you can't just pick up one item, move it over another and just swap it. You have to first pick up an item, drag it into empty area, put it down, go to the other item, drag it to the first items original area to place it then pickup the first item and move it the original place of second item. Fiddling with inventory like this adds nothing to the game and just wastes players time.
Overall the inventory management takes more time than it needs to take, especially compared to similar backpack management games that have more mechanics and depth but still taking less time to do things in inventory.

Balance:
Some characters have way better starting loadout than others.
Some stats are way better than other stats with luck being pretty much the best stat you can get by order of magnitude. What makes it so good is the issue with how you get stronger weapons and the fact that space is often the most limiting factor in how strong you are, so being able to fill up said space with higher tier items is extremely valuable. Also all of the more fun, interesting and build defining items are of high tier so if you like fun, you have to stack as much luck as you can get away with to have a higher chance of said items appearing.
For example lets say you want a tier 3 automatic crossbow. There are 3 ways to get said weapon.
(1) Just get lucky and have it appear in the shop as tier3 and buy it straight up for 98g from the shop, this one is by far the cheapest and fastest way and luck increases you chance to get lucky and see higher tier weapons and items.
(2) Upgrade your tier2 automatic crossbow that you bough for 57g using arcane anvil that is tier2 item and costs 80g for a total of 137g, luck helps with this method as well as it both increases the chance of getting the anvil as well as finding tier2 automatic crossbow.
(3) Buy 3 tier1 automatic crossbows for 35g each, have the space to hold them in inventory, they each take 6 slots, combine them for 57g into tier2 automatic crossbow, the cost of combining them is the same as just buying the outright, do that again twice to get two more tier2 crossbows and combine all three tier2 crossbows for 98g into tier3 automatic crossbow for a grand total of 584g.

Progression:
At the beginning of the game as you play, you get a tiny amount of meta progression resource to upgrade your characters between runs, you can get them more quickly by playing the harder difficulties that you unlock. You can spend said resource to either make your character stronger, to purchase items to add to the item pool, for some quality if life improvements or to increase how many resources you get. These options pretty much make it so that the last thing you should be buying are more items that increase variety and fun if you want to spend your time efficiently and should instead buy more resource gain and power to be able to play more effectively on harder difficulty. So the best way to play is not the most fun way to play, it is to ignore adding interesting and unique items and just more resource gain and power.

Sound and Music:
They are there, but they are strictly functional and do not evoke any sense of excitement and do not make a game better that much. The game could be with no sound at all and it would not really make it any worse than it is.

So, over the last year, I've played a bunch of "Vampire Survivors"-like. Each one bring something unique. They all have their strengths and weaknesses. And I expected God of Weapons to be that, a unique mix of VS and Backpack Hero. Instead it seems the devs of this game I've played several fun indie games, took mechanic from them, made them worse, and mixed them together into this game.

From Vampire Survivors, they took the idea of roaming around the map while your weapons auto attack. However, the only map in Vampire Survivors is a small rectangle, sometimes with a few obstacles in the way. There is nothing to discover, the map is just an area to dodge in, not a fun thing to play with and find secrets with like VS various maps. To spice things up, you can try to do achievements like in VS...except GoW lock achievements behind other achievements. Some achievements can only be done if you've done other achievements, even though they are technically unrelated. Worse, the achievements have not been well thought out. Some classes have multiple achievements related to them, others classes have none. A lot of fun aren't particularly fun or interesting.
Finally, they also took the idea of various weapons doing a lot of stuff onscreen, except the game is harder to read, and more importantly, provide no information about how much damages or kills each weapon or item is doing, so you're left in the dark regarding what works and what doesn't, so builds become guessworks

Talking about builds, it seems they took the idea of a complex set of stats and great number of weapons from Brotato. Except, contrary to their inspiration, they didn't provide a single explanation about what each stat does, they have hidden stats (like Pierce), item descriptions are unclear, or sometimes entirely wrong. As a Brotato player, I could recognize the way they displayed skills, and I could guess what the icons meant, but somebody who hasn't played Brotato before will have a much worse time. Even worse, a lot of stats and items seem really unbalanced, with some completely useless, and some must have. The build variety is therefore much worse than in Brotato, you're mostly gonna gravitate around a few concepts, and getting better at the game will only make it more obvious (whereas Brotato was great at encouraging you to try new things, and find new interesting builds that actually work).

Finally, for the last obvious feature, the inventory, the obvious inspiration is Backpack Hero. But once again, they made it worse. Items interactions in the bag are much more limited than in Backpack Hero, and more importantly, they made it a pain to reorganize your pack. Whereas Backpack Hero will allow you to freely remove stuff from your pack temporarily to complete reorganize everything, God of Weapons only give you 2 slots (one of which needs to be unlocked) to put items temporarily out of your backpack. Considering the number of items there are in your pack, it's woefully inadequate, and most of the time you will just let things as they are even if it's not the most efficient, because redoing your whole pack is just awful.

So, in the end, my advice is clear, skip God of Weapons, and instead, play Vampire Survivors, Brotato and/or Backpack Hero, which are all fantastic games in their own unique way.

Great entry in the survivors-like genre. I was originally drawn in by the humorous way your character keeps stacking more weapons on their back. Most games gloss over the fact that your character is often carrying, and using, 10s of weapons at once. Silly when you think about, but its video games after all. I'm really glad this pulled me in because the game is a really interesting take on the genre. There are two phases to every level. The combat phase is well done, but fairly standard survivors-like with dodging and powerups. The other phase is expanding and filling your inventory. While on the face of it this might seem like an annoyance, it really becomes a sort of puzzle game in its own right. You want to purchase powerful items that fit your build. But you also need to fit them in  your inventory and the items are all of different shapes and sizes. And you also get adjacency bonuses by placing them next to other items. The inventory phase becomes like a sort of packing puzzle, optimization mini game. I found that I really enjoyed this as a way to min/max your build as opposed to most games where you just pick from a list of options. Definitely a game worth checking out if you're a fan of the genre.

If you like the aesthetics and the idea of collecting weapons that will float around you and mow down huge swathes of creatures, this is a great game for you! There's no "story" really, just the fighting, so the focus is on the looks and functional details of the weapons and items you unlock and collect.

This rogue-like has everything I love about the genre - a strong visual style, the dangling carrot of visible but locked progression of new characters that keeps me coming back again and again, a pretty fast run time per round of approx 30 minutes, and lots of tiny, granular choices that affect the outcome of each individual fight and floor. The god-like aspect comes in from the auto-battle aspect of not having to press a button to activate the weapons - they float around your character and attack independently - the only thing the player, and the character, has to do is walk and dash. (The Dash ability is explained in a very simple tutorial pop-up, which could be improved by mentioning the cooldown timer - you cannot spam dash to avoid attacks like a dark souls game - the Dash is only for escaping a cluster of enemies once every 2 seconds.)

This game's simplicity of design is both a positive and a flaw - on the positive side, it really gets the player into the action quickly, gets them to learn by doing, and is not intrusive visually during runs. There is no "story" that requires brain power to follow or remember between runs, there is only the fight! This makes this game really attractive to play for stress relief, for that feeling of slowly but surely improving and broadening one's options.

On the negative side, there is not enough tutorial to explain the menu between floors - it took me several floors to notice the re-roll button for the shop on the left, several runs for me to notice the Lock function that keeps an item pinned so that it remains between floors and is unaffected by the Shop Refresh within the same floor. And several HOURS before I noticed it is possible to pay gold to shuffle the spots on offer to expand your inventory after a Level Up!

The only change I would strongly recommend is to add a second table or book to the starting area's Armory Room, to allow us to view available weapons and items and their stats. AND explanations of those stats. So the player can more easily plan their runs in-game without needing external guides or notes. For example, there is no way to know from the game's text alone what "Luck" does, that info is only found elsewhere online. To keep the sleek and simplified visual aesthetic, I think this info can be semi-hidden in a menu or an optional location, like the Armory room itself is.

Another feature I would like is the ability to (outside of runs) zoom in on character models while they are all standing around on the ground floor. Or, have their models show up with lots of detail visible, in a Journal option in the menu, or something like that. If i want to make canon-accurate fan art of the Berserker, I'd like to be able to see all the outfit details! :)

I have 21 hours in this game at time of review, so I'm not sure if this feature will be available later, but I would like something like the "banish" option found in Vampire Survivors, where the player can remove items from appearing the shop's offerings. There are two ways I can imagine to do this - either add a book containing all the unlocked items (as mentioned above), and allow a certain number of Banish Slots that could be increased at the Altar, to be spent on hiding or banishing the items from that book, where any item could be toggled on or off between runs, and the Banish Slots are refunded easily. (That is how VS does it.) 

Or, a gold-pay option in the Shop, where the player would see an item in the Shop between floors, an dwould have the options to Lock, Buy, or Banish the item. After picking Banish, that item would not appear in the shop again during that run. If the player made a mistake, it is already very easy to abandon a run in the menu and start a new one, so that makes for simple management.

This is a Meat Game (i.e. "X meets Y"), in this case it's Vampire Survivors meets Backpack Hero, and there isn't a dang thing about this game that doesn't scream "formula-driven". The thing is, if either one of those styles of play is capable of sucking you in, then God Of Weapons will do so, EFFICIENTLY.

My main complaint, and indeed the main reason I'm so surprised I spent so much time on this thing, is that all meta-advancement is so you can get better at fighting the same enemies in the same environment, on repeat, forever. There's only one type of environment, a stone dungeon looking thing that is a slightly different size every time, and occasionally has a couple token obstacles or spike traps. There's plenty of characters to unlock, and each character has different "aspects", all of which change the build strategy, but really all you need to know is, what bonuses does this character/aspect give you, and from there you just buy the items that go with that.

The arrangement mechanics are probably what sucked me in the hardest. The more powerful weapons have harder shapes to work with, and the rules for expanding your inventory space include a random element that ensures you'll always be one space short of goal and using the "lock item" feature to hold an item until your next buy phase. But I can genuinely say this grabbed me, and it's satisfying to pull off an arrangement that turns the ever-growing goon squad into gibs and loot drops.

All in all, I can say I got way more than my money's worth out of this, and Bonk help me, I'm probably gonna go play it some more after I write this. But I won't be proud of myself.

Firstly, I'm writing this review after completing all content in the game. I thought it would be interesting to do it this time around since the achievements seemed pretty straight forward.
Well, to start I think this game was easy to understand and get into, the themes were interesting, bringing generic rpg classes into a  "climb the tower" story, told only by game mechanics and environment. Different characters can be unlocked as you explore these game mechanics and they have class variations that customize gameplay even further; The Graphics are generally nice and pleasing to watch, as well as many visual effects from the weapons themselves. The game features an inventory management system that lets you customize your play patterns  and adds difficulty to the game.

Now, there are several specific good and bad things I found while playing the game and would like to describe here so others can understand better what I've been talking about:


CHARACTER DESIGN:
Designs and their variations are usually appealing, with the king one having the most different 3d models variants. However, there seem to be some random sexualized characters such as the lancer and priestess which have common tropes such as boob a thigh windows and "battle lingerie". Finally, in general, all skins are ok, but feature very few differences between themselves mostly being color variations and different accessory models, which, don't get me wrong, are usually fine but sometimes make it hard to discern which class variation is it.

WEAPONS:
Most weapons look super cool, not only the models, but also in game as they attack. There are enough variations and types of weapons, making it possible to pivot and develop your game plan throughout the floors as well as just keep it simple and use one type of weapon the whole run. Personally, I didn't like the dual blades and the big lifesteal scythe for their attack patterns and damage weren't worth the space. My favorite ones were normal dagger, thunder spear, trident, cannon and throwing hammers.

ITEMS and STATS:
Unfortunately I don't think most items were interesting, many of them are just stats tradeoffs, with only tier 3 and 4 actually changing how things work. But, as weird as that sounds the most useful items are those stat ones at the beginning, they will set your survival for the whole run. That said, the importance of those attributes vary, not only as you progress through the game, but also as you understand what actually makes you live. Earlier on, having tons of blow horns will secure survival and help you understand enemy patterns and such. But later on things like Range and Attack Speed will keep most of the enemies at bay. However, there are some problems still, I think that the payoffs for having negative movement speed outvalue practically everything else and it is almost always correct to go for it in almost all scenarios. The real problem here is that there should be more payoffs for having more speed for example.

MECHANICS and BALANCING:
First of all the normal camera was hard to play with, even with just a small tweak by changing it in the settings some of the hitboxes of projectiles are not as precise as they seem. This is a minor feedback, for the major problem and basically the ranged winged elite that shoots projectiles and the final boss’s spinning aoe effect. For some reason this enemy is harder than the final boss in any difficulty and the final boss’s spinning sword aoe skill have very little visual effects to cue this ability is happening in the middle of some many other enemies.

BACKPACK MANAGEMENT:
Ok, this part is not well done. This feature is not fluid, it’s hard to reorganize items, there is no way to simply remove all items and such. The idea is good, but the released feature is kinda clunky. I wished it was something more similar to the new released game Backpack Battles, which really gives the player the capacity to manage the grid tetris to their favor.

REVIEW IN HOPES THAT DEV FIXES SOME OF THE BELOW ITEMS AND BECAUSE I CAN'T LEAVE A MIXED REVIEW:
I recommend this game only because of the price point; it's worth $5 on sale.

b) The game will crash sometimes, and there goes your run

7) Sometimes the bottom of the inventory gets bugged and it won't let you buy a weapon that would obviously fit there until you beat the next floor and come back to the shop. This happened multiple times, and yes I quadruple-checked that the weapon would fit in the spot.

Like the name of the game implies, it's about the weapon combinations that make any particular build viable... but more importantly, there's basically an inventory management mini-game/puzzle where you balance the needs of your character against where you're at in a given run.

That said, some details you might want to know about the game are:
1. There are elite monsters that'll show up, at a baseline of floors 10/15.  There are, however, only 2 types of elites that can appear: the succubus and the beholder.  That's it.
2. Similarly, there are only 2 bosses throughout the game.  One variety on the last floor of the lowest difficulty and one variety on the last floor of the remaining 4 difficulties.  
3. There are only 20 floors for each difficulty at a maximum.
4. There are a bunch of different weapon and character combinations.
5. Much of the weapon access is gated by achievements on previous characters.

There is something to be said on the limited variety on elites and bosses.  There's something to be said about how 20 floors can stop feeling like a challenge.  It can feel [i]disappointing[/i] to see the "victory" appear at the end when you want to keep going.  But it's important to recognize that it's disappointing because this game is, most importantly, [b]fun[/b].  Therefore, this game has a hearty endorsement from me.

I would also like to clarify that a broad sense of a good quality game is also defined by its value proposition.  For me, that's something close to 1 hour of legitimately fun gameplay (not gimmicky throttling) per dollar spent.  Even at the full price $6 I spent on this game, I well exceeded that and was happy to.

This is a unique Survivors-type rogue-like game that requires Tetris skills for inventory management to boost your stats / performance.  Yes, that sounds odd, but it works well.

You choose a class, and get tossed into the dungeon with a starter weapon.  Gameplay involves running and dashing around a dungeon room, trying to avoid getting touched or shot by mobs.  Break one of the barrels which randomly appear, and you could find one of a few power-ups, health-boosting food or a stick of dynamite that blows up after a few seconds.  

Mobs often drift towards you, asking to have their necks cut by your trusty whateverweaponyourecarrying.  Some, though, will snipe at you from a distance, forcing you to dash in their direction and take them out before they add to the bullet hell rooms can become.  All of this time, you collect gold, which is used to buy stuff between each floor.

That "stuff buying" is what makes this game unique.  You only have a limited inventory space, so whatever you buy has to fit in the grid that will expand slightly as you beat each dungeon floor.  One of the tricky parts is that you're offered expansion before you buy anything, so you have to watch what's available, and hope the RNG grid expansion choices let you create a shape where the stuff can fit.

The "stuff" you're buying consists of weapons and stat boosters which only last until you die.  After a dozen floors, your inventory is crammed with weapons, each of which is used to fight off the mobs; have 6 swords in there, and you're a walking food processor, pureeing mobs as needed.

Trying to assemble and balance inventory is a crucial part of this game, adding a bit of jigsaw-like puzzling to make sure you're using your available space as efficiently as possible.

Honestly, before playing I thought the game might suck a bit - but it doesn't.  While the graphics are a little isometric-cartoony, the atmosphere and slightly-frantic pace of the gameplay keep you engaged.

This is a unique twist on the Survivors genre, and it works.

I love this game. It feels like the perfect mix of Brotato's gameplay loop and Backpack Battle's shop phase, with each being a vital component to the game and neither of them failing to stimulate different sides of my brain to ensure neither get too stale.

The good: 
I love puzzle games and Tetris, so trying to fit all my items into my backpack is genuinely fun, and racking my head around which items should stay, which should be upgraded is probably one of my largest time sinks in this game

The gameplay is good enough for what this game is trying to be, I don't feel like I'm sweating trying to get through every wave, but I can feel my heart race when I take far too much damage too quickly and count down the seconds just praying that I survive.

The diversity is amazing, every class having 2 additional subclasses to unlock with 2 additional relics that will change the way you think of building every time you go in, giving you plenty of choices to pick from, or challenges to work towards if you're finding that your struggling with what you current have available to you.

The Enemies are all different and behave different, while the general action is to [Move Towards Player] they all have their own movements, their own attacks, patterns which you learn and adapt to the more you play and enemies you come to fear and try to plan around because you know how devastating 8 small slimes or 7 baby scorpions can be when you have no AOE, they matter and will make sure you are playing to the best of your ability, easily punishing you for overconfidence trying to reach a barrel for a couple of dollars.

The levels vary in size and obstacle amount, while it might seem small, I love that I have to change my playstyle based around the enemies currently spawning and the layout of the floor I'm currently on, long yet thin levels feel compact and intimate, like every point of attack speed will count as all the enemies have no choice but to spawn next to me, where as large open levels feel like dodge, move speed, range, and smart dash usage feel much more important as enemies can launch ranged attacks from much further away and I can't just be a sitting duck (unless my build revolves around that)

The Okay:

I love the items, how they feel and how they look, but judging from the discussion boards and even some of the problems I've had, some items that have additional effects than just a flat stat boost like "Set your HP to 1 at the start of the round after this was purchased" or "Gives +8% Bounce for each adjacent Throwing Weapons" While functional and very cool, could definitely use better visibility to avoid people thinking they were bugs, or working improperly (The +8% Bounce applies TO the adjacent weapons, not to the base weapon as I had thought from the wording)

The Meta currency, affording you power ups for future runs and the ability to purchase stronger items to appear in future shops. I'm a bit mixed as while I wish there would challenges to unlock the items instead of just buying them with boss currency and challenge keys, they are fine and I can give them a pass. I'm a bit saddened that there isn't a big currency sink from what I've seen after you've purchased everything you can (Not that I have any ideas what it could be) and that they'll just kinda pile up, leaving the only purpose for a full difficulty 5 clear on all characters just being satisfaction that all their subclass names are Orange.

The Bad:

Item managing, specifically the inability to not just rotate, but fully flip the item. Some items have weird shapes and I with I could position them in a way that better suits forming a dense shape around my starting relic, but I am sadly not afforded that option because my items can only be rotated in 1 of 4 directions, no ability to flip non-symmetrical items. while this isn't usually an issue later in the runs as you'll usually get a much larger backpack and a lot more items to help fill in and spaces that are left open, it hurts just a little bit not having a visually pleasing backpack at the end of the run to be able to show my friends to convince them to buy the game

Boss Diversity is also lacking, all of the enemies are visually and functionally difference and usually start appearing at predictable points in the run if it calls for it, but no matter what item you consume or socket into your backpack, you'll only be greeted by 1 of 2 minibosses, and while they are well telegraphed and hit equally as hard, I wish there were more of them to send shock through me and make me consider my build further before telling the game to send 5 at me because I know I can take 'em all. The same goes for the boss, I wish there was another we could see, as I think every time I've gotten to them, I've only died once to them, and I've only beat the game through time due to lack of DPS once, so more variation is welcome!

I love this game and am going to go for 100%, I can only hope the devs have more in store for the game, more characters, more items, possibly even new game modes with endless or hyper speed for bragging purposes. You guys did AWESOME and I'm so happy there are so many bundles for different games for a cool deal and different experiences depending on which parts of the game you enjoyed and which you didn't.

God of weapons takes the genre created by Vampire Survivors and expanded by many other titles and adds a very clever inventory management system, which may sound strange in a genre so frantic but it works wonders and adds some nice complexity to the familiar game loop.

The game runs in timed stages where you run between a lot of enemies trying to kill and survive at the same time but, in between, you get to manage a square divided inventory (like the ones on Resident Evil or the old Diablo)  where you need to put the weapons and items and potions that you buy in a randomized store. Some Items have synergies between and different qualities  them so carefully managing them is vital to your survival and to your build optimization and this change of rythm between the game loop and the inventory management section works great.

On top of that, you have many different classes and subclasses that create their own synergies with some weapons or items (IE: Knight favours armor and big weapons, rogue has more damage the more daggers you have, etc...) And you unblock many more by completing milestones and achievements. 

It is A LOT of fun for the price, so I highly recommend it if you like the genre and if you love to manage inventories.

First: Buy it. For $6 the entertainment value you'll get is astounding.

That being said, lets get to *why* you should buy it:
If you're familiar with the Vampire Survivors genre, you know that most VS games follow a similar formula. You enter a map and face waves of enemies that grow in size and power over the course of 20 to 30 minutes while leveling up and building your equipment with the goal of surviving to the end.

The problem with these games is that, once you become knowledgeable of what works and what doesn't, with a little luck you'll hit a point where you can basically just set the controller down and watch as your character stands still killing everything on the screen. It becomes a glorified screensaver and loses the thrill and engagement you had when you were starting out and eventually becomes boring to play.

God of Weapons gets around this by splitting the level up into stages. Rather than one continuous 20 minute level, you'll fight on 20 stages that each last 45-ish seconds. Between each stage you must manage your inventory, and that's where the real magic is. 

I didn't expect to like this aspect, but it turns out that expanding and managing your inventory is a game in and of itself and fiddling with the puzzle of getting the most out of it works to engage with and bring your focus back to the game regardless of how well you're doing during the fights. The game is generous with the resources you use to buy items and upgrades so you can put quite a bit of effort into perfecting your build for the run.

I've never played one of these Bullet Heaven games before (a lot of them always seemed a bit too automatic for me), but watching the trailer was enough to convince me to give this one a try.

Things to like:
The way all your weapons are just wildly attacking things of their own accord while your character just stands there and looks cool, like the most powerful wizard/jedi/dark lord to ever exist, is really enjoyable to watch.

The inventory puzzling thing is, in my opinion, a really good way (though, certainly not for everyone) to make an otherwise uninteresting character advancement system (“choose from one of these three options, one of them is clearly the best one”) into something that can be legitimately challenging (“I could easily get the tier 2 frost wand and fit it in here, but if I can just move things around enough to get these spaces over to those spaces, I HAVE the space for that tier 4 fireball staff... Or do I just admit defeat and sell one of these horns, but do I have enough self-healing to risk having less barrels spawning???”)

Dozens of character builds to try out and loads of replayability. Even without the progression system, this game would have staying power.

I really just like the look of the game. The glowing eyes, the way the warlock floats, the generally practical/normal looking outfits, the less over-the-top weapon designs, all the funky little magic items.

Things to dislike:
Not enough classes. I want MORE!

Things I’d like to see:
More of everything. More characters, more weapons, more magic items, more, more, more.

Having said that, as you unlock all the cool items in the forge, your selection of items in the shop gets more and more bogged down with things you might not want for a given run. Certain types of runs, like single weapon type runs (all throwing daggers, all anything small, really) become harder and harder to achieve as a result. It’s a minor problem, but the simple addition of a sixth slot in the shop that is usually empty but has a chance to have an item in it that goes up by a small amount for each item you unlock would solve that problem.

An infinite mode would be pretty cool. Where you could max out your inventory and face increasingly numerous hordes...

There needs to be a co-op. Even if it were just tacked on, with no balance changes, even if it were local co-op only, even though I have no friends and would never play it with anyone, it needs to happen.

If I mouse over a stat, it’d be pretty cool if it highlighted every item in my inventory that was modifying that stat.

The ability to right click one of the blessings to refund a level in it without having to refund all my blessings to free up a few titanite shards would be a welcome addition.

But the main thing I’d like to see is a balancing of the various stats that doesn’t just nerf whatever’s fun or popular, because I’ve been burned by that kind of balance before.

[b] Cons: [/b]
- typos and weird descriptions here and there, nothing game breaking, just not as polished as you might think 
- rounds based system might not be for everyone, rounds are 30sec - 1min long with shopping in between
- the arena that you are fighting in is quite small, which makes it difficult to navigate and survive early on while your build is developing and on the flip side once your build picks up, you can't get enough mobs to kill, your weapons have big enough range to kill everything across the arena so you just stand in a corner and kill the mobs practically off-screen.
- definitely needs more balancing for monsters and items, the game feels too easy and too hard at the same time, and maybe 20% of the time it's just right. Starting off with the lesser evil: certain item just make or break the build and you are not guaranteed to even get them. With that in mind I would just like the devs to review certain underused items and maybe combine them with others or scrap them altogether, this would reduce item bloat. Like I said, I finished this game and certain items I either haven't found a use for or it's so situational that it would be better of combined with something else. Hopefully devs have some stats on underused items to take a look at.
- and lastly the main balancing gripe that I have are certain mob types. For example you could get oneshot with a solid build if you happen to run to a wall and get charged by an elite that is sliding alongside the wall, practically shotgunning you. Or even if you happen to be at the end of their charge, you always seem to take more instances of dmg from them, so maybe they should give you a grace period after getting hit by that elite mob specifically. It's worth including in the review because that thing was the reason for at least half my deaths and is bound to happen to YOU. So to sum it all u some things are just over- and under tuned. But it's by no means unplayable you get your workarounds and get used to it.


[b] Pros: [/b]
- their twist on itemization with the inventory management is a unique idea and should be your main reason to try to this game because it feels like you are playing 2 games at once, very enjoyable though! (For reference you play 20 rounds to finish the game. Each round is 30sec going up to 60 sec, but lets say a round is 1min each. You would need 20 minutes to finish the gameplay aspect, however my fastest game was  41 minutes and that's after I knew exactly what I was doing. Before then you can expect your games to last an average of 50 minutes consistently, which just facilitates my point that you are literally playing two games.)
- plenty of things to unlock and builds to try, as stated above 60 hours worth of entertainment for this price tag is a steal
- item synergies via item tags, most items have tags that give them additional bonuses if placed adjacent to a synergistic item, which makes the inventory management intriguing
- and speaking of item tags, this is something that can easily be experimented and expanded upon in future updates

[b] All in all, if you are looking to get your vampire survivor fix but want something unique, this will hit the spot for sure. The devs have a great foundation here and will hopefully improve and build upon it! [/b]

Who knew that bullet heavens had so much to gain by borrowing from Resident Evil 4? God of Weapons may not inundate you with Spanish zombies but it does gamify the grid based inventory management of the 2005 Capcom Classic and combines it with a bullet heaven.

The result is glorious: you get the same sort of escalating power thrills of all the best games that have ‘survivors’ in the title but it also turns the build crafting process into this constant negotiation where upgrades take up physical space and are competing with the rest of your powers.

A bland aesthetic and lack of contextualization for its inventory systems ensure that God of Weapons is only as good as it’s mechanics, but thankfully those mechanics are both massively compelling and endlessly replayable.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3039381541

I think the highest compliment I can give God of Weapons is how obvious it was that this wasn’t their first time taking a crack at the genre: developer Archmage Labs previously made “Beautiful Mystic Survivors” which takes full advantage of the fact that this genre is typically played with one hand. Despite the fact I haven’t played it, it’s not lacking for glowing reviews that swear they’re only playing it for the articles.

That survivors pedigree is made manifest in some subtle choices—strong execution of genre staple mechanics and smart cherry picking it’s done from its peers. It’s got Brotatos economy management and discrete waves to ensure building and upgrading has its own dedicated time instead of disrupting the combat. It’s got a Soulstone Survivor’s esque cross character dash that allows for a low cooldown position reset if needed. But most importantly it’s got that RE 4 inventory management, more directly filtered through the lens of modern indies like Backpack hero which wrap a whole game around the concept and add perks like modifiers and adjacency bonuses.

All those influences fit like a glove: the inventory management specifically isn’t just a gimmick but a complete reconteztualizarion for each choice you make. The leveling process itself isn’t granting you all that much statistical power, it’s real merit comes from giving you one more choosable square on the inventory grid.

And therein lies some pretty compelling questions: you’ll have your usual survivors concerns like getting enough flat damage to get through early game and enough scaling damage to get through late, but now you have to think about how those things interact in a physical container.

You’ll oftimes start by designing your weapons around your space but you have enough agency to design your space around your weapons: when that max rarity hammer pops into the shop you’ll be tempted to find the 8 lopsided grid squares it demands to take advantage of that power.

There’s a lot of more minute shuffling to be done in addition to that though: each class has a different starting item that typically applies benefits to neighboring weapons or armor, so there’s this jigsaw meta game of trying to align your inventory in a way that both minimizes open space but also ensures your passive boosts are touching the right items.

There’s a transience to the inventory as well: the ability to sell any item gives your playthroughs a level of mid-run flexibility and pivoting opportunities that God of Weapons’ peers typically don’t have. It prevents your builds from ever becoming autopiloted regardless of how deep into a run you are.

What shouldn’t be unspoken is how well God of Weapons executes on the genres tenants. Even completely independent of its bespoke inventory management upgrade system, it nails the satisfaction that comes with overpowering the swarm that’s enclosing you. The scrolling combat text is readable and simple, the soundscape nails the gratification that comes with the layered audio impact of cleaving dozens of minions at once, and by virtue of the fact this is a full 1.0 release rather than the genres love for early access, it came out the gate with around a dozen classes each of which has three subclasses.

Brisk 20 minute durations always tempt a follow up run, coupled with a meta progression and item unlock system that multiplies the amount of weapons and armor in the game. 

It does have some balancing problems which, according to one of their first post release dev communications, is something they’re already looking at. One of the obvious culprits is items that use increased horde size as a downside to offset powerful bonuses, but in practice it’s the elite and boss monsters giving you the heartache not the horse itself so it’s hardly a penalty.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3039381859

It’s current biggest drawback is a modest presentation that might have some folks scrolling right past it’s store page and  prevent them from ever getting to the juicy systems underneath. This knight lugging around a sack of pointy sticks in the key art isn’t a visual motif that carries into the actual gameplay in any way. Armor gets no optical representation at all and weapons unceremoniously float around you—a budget concession I think I’d be more willing to jump on board with had the visual themes enforced it more: like controlling powerful gods who need not bother with grips and handles, instead of these regular ol’ fantasy classes that are all telepathic I guess.

It may not be a looker but don’t make the mistake of passing it by for that reason; from a pure gameplay sense this is the one you’ve been waiting for. God of Weapons borrows a lot but it borrows smartly. There’s no system in here you haven’t seen before but their integration add a tremendous amount of texture to every decision and every run. A flexible inventory based building system, varied classes and subclasses, and punchy-satisfying auto attacking combat ensure this title isn’t just a God of Weapons, but a God of Survivors games too.

This is the first action roguelike that I tried, having been turned off by most other games in the genre. Once I got the hang of things I rarely found myself losing a run if I made it to the 10th wave and succeeded after getting the hang of things. 

There are certainly some bugs and balance issues with some of the weapons/classes, like not being able to complete the "complete a run with all variants of a class" until you've unlocked all versions of the class. Some attack animations will just outright miss, which is especially noticeable in the early levels when you only have a few weapons. This meant I found myself favoring certain weapon types with every run. One greataxe can carry a run because of the whirlwind, a shock weapon can sometimes permastun elites. Projectile weapons, specifically crossbows, just felt bad every time I used them. 

But that's all minor to the amount of fun I had once I got the hang of things. There have already been a few patches to rebalance some items, and address the somewhat slow meta progression. Excited to see if an endless mode of some kind is added, or really something to encourage playing the same class again after beating difficulty 5.

Brotato mixed with inventory management. I only played a bit of Brotato, but refunded it due to lack of meta progression. This game provides it and if you bought the game at release, you would know that it was going to/took a lot of time to max out everything. However, there have been patches not even a week after this game's release that made it easier to get the currency to unlocking some of the upgrades and as well as adding more types of upgrades. The game was good before these patches, but now the game is a considerably less grindy. What I like about this game is the accessories that you equip to your build because there is a huge variety of them that makes all weapons viable. There are a good cast of playable characters and each character has three stat variations/unique passives to them. The game has great graphics as well. 

Some of the cons I would like to point out are the camera angle and the hitboxes. The former issue might contribute to my problem with the hitboxes. This game is third person, but unlike most games of this genre, it is not topdown. The angle you are given makes it easy to get hit by offscreen projectiles. As you get farther in the game and you are overwhelmed by the enemies and their projectiles, you will dash into what you think is open area (because you can't see it) and suddenly get hit a stray enemy projectile or a mob of monsters. Then there are the hitboxes, which are hard to tell where they start and end. Going by what you see on the screen isn't always going to be best your bet when dodging, because it seems like the hitboxes are about 10% bigger than what you would expect. It might not seem like a lot but when threading the needle of projectiles, this affects gameplay drastically.

Quick review: 

I've been looking at variation on the theme of Vampire Survivor for a while, knowing that the genre has yet to evolve but holds some real potential. So far, in addition to God of Weapons, I've played the OG Magic Survival on Android, 20 Minutes to Dawn and Soulstone Survivor. 

What struck me in this title is that rounds are cleared based on a very short countdown which, even during the first run, encourages you to pile-up life-leech items and run in circles until it's over. I haven't seen any specific reasons to face the mobs or take any risk. I 'won' my very first run and wasn't compelled to try another. 

While 20MtD and SS go an extra mile, gameplay wise, to add a cursor and let you prioritize your target, while SS proposes colorful setting and enemies, God Of Weapons feels like a step back with a drab artistic direction and no possibility to aim. I couldn't find any rewarding/motivating feeling during my run -no overwhelming attacks, no split second decision about positioning and targeting, just running around. 

I feel bad for asking a refund for a game that cost me that little, especially since it's on Unity and we all know Unity now treats its developers like milking cows, but at this point I'd rather find another game to support. 

Nice try, but not there yet.

WHAT IT IS: A solid mash-up of the gameplay of "Brotato" and the inventory management of "Backpack Hero".  The meta progression is important here, which is quite different from the way Brotato works.

WHAT IT ISN'T: It's not Vampire Survivors/Soulstone Survivors/Halls of Torment.  The arenas are smaller and the action isn't quite so over the top like the titles mentioned.  If you are looking for heavy skill usage and many abilities firing off at once with flashy graphics... this one is a little more tame.

THE GAMEPLAY LOOP: You take a character (classes unlock in a similar way to Halls of Tormet and others) into a small arena and fight monsters, with the aim of surviving until the timer counts down (1 minute or less, etc).  Once timer hits 0, you advance to the real game, inventory management.  You buy items with in-game currency (earned in each arena) and try to arrange your weapons, armour and artifacts to maximize both impact and synergy for the next battle.  

After 20 of these fights, you have beaten that difficulty level and you get a victory screen.  You will then have a small amount of currency to redeem for meta-progression power-ups OR you can go to the Armoury/Shop and add items to the potential item pool for future runs.  

You unlock more and more characters (each with 3 different playstyles) and grind that meta progression to your heart's content.  

DIFFICULTY: It's more difficult than the average entry, IMHO.  I say this because the game really does expect you to reach certain levels of power to be able to clear the higher difficulties.  So, when you plan your purchases and upgrades, you do need to pay attention and ESPECIALLY, apply what you learned on your next run. 

Meta progression rewards aren't very plentiful when compared to the genre as a whole.  So, it isn't quite a game where you can zone out and cruise.  Combat is simple enough, but to really kick some ass you will need a little luck and some smart planning.  

FUN FACTOR: It is early, as I am like 20-something hours into it.  But, I think this game is about as fun as the genre can offer right now, given the size of the arena and the progression model.   If you do want the flashier experience with more enemies, etc... you might not enjoy the gameplay as much.

VERDICT:  Definitely an easy recommend.  My only caveat being that the focus of the game isn't the actual combat itself, but planning your choices and adjusting when needed.  I have seen people lose patience with the game, so keep that in mind if you want a faster, more intense progression model.  Still, if you give this one a chance (even if you struggle) it is super worth in the end.

The game is not boring at all, yet many aspects remain immature.
1. It is quite confusing to have a non-linear armor. Stacking armor for only ~10, which is the case for many character, is totally unworthy. To illustrate this point, just imagine the case: is it the same for one to increase 0% damage reduction to 1% or to increase 99% damage reduction to 100%? If your answer is no, you definitely understand what I mean. In game, it seems useless for many characters, even for some melee weapon users, to stack the armor; yet for some character, the combination of armor & shield is just op. If you are playing the melee rogue-raven, what will you stack for survival? For me, I'd put the attack speed at the first, and then the range, and then the recover & life-steal, and at the least willing to even buy a single item for it, the armor. It is not a healthy design at all.
2. Bad balancing. For items or weapons, one would expect the items with same rarity have roughly the same value, with some are just slightly more op. However, we could say that about 50% of the items are trash, with 20% of the items to be much more op. For instance, the stopwatch and the gloves, they are too flexible and too op, compared to other blue damage items. And so on for survival & long-run items. For weapons, spell weapons and some of the melee weapons are just too weak and too slot consuming. I'd expect at least the long sword, which takes 5 slots, to be at least 25% more stronger than the short sword, which takes 4 slots. To be honest, I'd rather say I expect 30%~40% for the extra value, since the extra cost to arrange the backpack. Same, for rods, polearms and all weapons with "bad shapes", they are expected to be stronger. However, the long sword is nothing stronger than the short sword, except if you want a long sword to take full advantage of your armor items. The polearms are also badly behaved in game, I don't think they are a good choice for now.
3. It is strange to have dash & movement speed together. There's some point to stack the movement speed in Brotato etc., but it is totally useless to have movement speed as a "movement buff", as the dash is already good enough for moving. One reason why stopwatch is op is it actually reduce the movement speed, which makes some items to exploit the negative movement speed.
I really enjoyed the game, yet I'm really sorry to say that there are too many problems for a post-beta game. I hope that there will be a major rework and balancing patch for the game.

There's definitely something here, but it needs some polishing. If you like Survivor-style games and inventory management, it's a no-brainer, but a few gripes which I hope will be worked out:

- SFX are weak and seem like an afterthought, which wouldn't be a big deal except that there's very little feedback when the player is being hurt. Combined with wonky hitboxes and the fact there are almost no i-frames when hit, you can die very fast in later difficulties without realizing you're even being harmed.

- Meta progression needs work. Outside of working towards specific quest goals, the only way to earn meta-currency is to kill mini-bosses or finish a whole 20-stage run, and it's very easy to make it to the final boss and die, effectively wasting an hour or so of play time.

- Weak level design. Feels really samey really fast, and lots of enemy types seem redundant. Not enough bosses / minibosses. Could fix this problem and the meta progression problem by adding a greater volume and variety of "elites."

- I was really hoping for more synergy between items based on adjacency / position relative to each other within the inventory. They could have really ran with that. Instead, you get a single unique item based on your character class that will improve adjacent items, and very few weapons / items that synergize with each other. Really hope this gets expanded on because it's kind of the whole gimmick. Thankfully, the game lends itself to expansion.

- A significant number of easily fixed flaws (lots of typos, bugged items which don't do what they say they do, SFX bugs, and why is the default position of all items upside-down?)

All in all, a good game that could be great with a little more love, and I can't complain for the generous price point. Hope the devs keep working on this.
